item.title: How to Get Hive Fruit Seed in Grow a Garden
item.description:
One of the most enjoyable aspects of Roblox's Grow a Garden is cultivating a diverse range of flowers, fruits, and vegetables on your digital farm . You can care for them by watering them regularly, setting up sprinklers, and arranging them however you like for a unique setup.

Hive Fruit is a brand-new crop you can grow that was introduced in the game's 1.08.0 update, and it's no exaggeration to say this fruit can make you money faster than most of the other available plants. It’s among the top valuable crops from the update. Here’s how to get the Hive Fruit Seed in Grow a Garden , along with a quick look at its selling value and why it’s worth planting.

How to Get Hive Fruit Seed in Grow a Garden

To get Hive Fruit Seed in Grow a Garden , head to the Honey Shop and buy it from there. It costs 40 Honey Jars . You can find this store by speaking to the Queen Bee in the event area. Once you speak with her, all the special items will become visible. If Hive Fruit Seed is in stock, grab it quickly. It’s a unique seed that appears in the store only occasionally (usually, only one seed shows up at a time).

Once it’s gone, it might take a while to return. Because of that, it’s a good idea to have some honey stored up so you’re ready to snag it. You can also pick up a Hive Fruit Seed anytime for 599 Robux if you're open to spending real money.

Pets with seed-digging ability can't find this crop seed for you.

Hive Fruit's Selling Value in Grow a Garden

Hive Fruit is a divine crop that can reproduce fruits, just like all Bee Swarm crops. When it was first introduced, its selling value was only 4,500 Sheckles. Thankfully, it received a major buff later on. Now, each Hive Fruit sells for an average of 45,125 Sheckles in Grow a Garden .

Interestingly, we experimented with growing Hive Fruit using one Basic, one Advanced, and one Godly sprinkler. Here are the prices we got for each fruit based on its weight and variants:

  • 8.25 kg Wet Hive Fruit: 106,296 Sheckles
  • 16.78 kg Hive Fruit: 219,870 Sheckles
  • 19.64 kg Hive Fruit: 301,290 Sheckles
  • 17.57 kg Wet Gold Hive Fruit: 9,644,832 Sheckles

We didn’t use the exact Sprinkler Method, but it still gave us valuable results. If you can, try the correct method on Hive Fruit. It helps them grow quite large and sell for even more.

Is Hive Fruit Seed Worth Buying in Grow a Garden?

The Hive Fruit is an absolute must-have plant for your farm, serving as a solid alternative to Moon Mango and Moon Blossom, particularly in terms of its base value. In fact, higher-weight Hive Fruits can even outperform Candy Blossom . So, if you missed out on those during past events, this event can still bring you fruits with similar (or even better) profitability. Unlike the flower crops from this update, Hive Fruit is easier to get since it can be bought straight from the store and doesn’t require opening tons of chance-based seed packs.

item.title: Best Western RPGs That Don't Use An Open-World, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • RPGs and open-world games often coexist, but the genres don't always need each other.
  • Borderlands offers a loose open-world structure with emphasis on looter-shooter gameplay.
  • Games like Dishonored and Mass Effect provide immersive experiences without expansive open worlds.

RPGs and open-world games often go hand-in-hand, and it's easy to see why. RPGs are often structured around some level of character customization and, especially in western RPGs, the ability to make decisions that affect the world and story. So, naturally, building a custom character and letting them freely explore a world shaped by their decisions only seems like a logical combination. There's a reason Bethesda had such huge success with The Elder Scrolls and Fallout , and CDProjekt Red found huge fanbases with The Witcher and Cyberpunk 2077 .

But this is not a requirement for either genre. After all, an open-world game doesn't need RPG mechanics; it just has to be open. Likewise, an RPG can still have all the things that draw people to Skyrim without offering an overwhelmingly large map to explore. Just because it has worked in the past doesn't mean it's always a good move. JRPGs are often characterized by having linear narratives in which characters follow a set path, and they still have plenty of critically acclaimed titles. Sometimes, a western RPG can also do something really interesting by changing things up and moving away from the open-world format to create a more unique experience.

6 The Borderlands Series

Borderlands 3
8 /10
13
8.1 /10
Released
September 13, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL
8 /10
13
8.1 /10

ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Sexual Themes, Strong Language
Powered by

The Borderlands series mixes RPG mechanics with fast-paced action, but its basic setup isn't really an open world. It's more like a set of loosely connected maps that are gradually unlocked as the story progresses. Sometimes, they can't even be accessed by conventional means and require the in-game transit network for players to reach them.

While the player can technically explore individual areas and revisit them at almost any time after being unlocked, it's not really the main focus. The main selling point of Borderlands is being a "looter-shooter." So, naturally, greater emphasis is placed on the chaotic cartoon carnage perpetrated by the player character and the loot that comes out of it. Even the missions that involve some level of exploration are typically structured more around completing an outlandish task than anything pertaining to the world.

5 Clair Obscur: Expedition 33

A Straightforward Journey Across A Strange World

10 Images
10 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Clair Obscur: Expedition 33
Turn-Based RPG
Fantasy

95
9.3 /10

Mature 17+ // Blood and Gore, Strong Language, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Developer(s)
Sandfall Interactive
Publisher(s)
Kepler Interactive

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

Powered by

Sandfall Interactive's critically acclaimed fantasy RPG combines a western RPG aesthetic with a JRPG-influenced structure. It is perhaps most obvious in the turn-based combat, but it's also clear with how the story and setting are presented. Instead of going the obvious route of an open world, Clair Obscur offers a fairly linear path that is structured around the journey of its protagonists. Similar to a lot of JRPGs, the map isn't so much an open world as a set of smaller locations the player visits over the course of the story, connected by an overworld.

Now, individual places sometimes have room for exploration, especially since a lot of them have maze-like designs that are easy to get lost in, and only the overworld gets an in-game map. Doing so can reveal secrets. However, this is completely optional, with the bulk of the game being built around reaching the next story objective.

4 The Dishonored Series

Open-Ended But Not Open-World

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Dishonored 2
FPS
Action
Systems
8.7 /10
Released
November 11, 2016
ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Strong Language, Suggestive Themes
Developer(s)
Arkane Studios
Publisher(s)
Bethesda

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Arkane's steampunk fantasy series has become well-known for its streamlining of the RPG format, allowing immersion, exploration, and a degree of player agency while simultaneously retaining simplicity. Unlike many of its parent company Bethesda's titles, Dishonored chooses to avoid an overwhelmingly large open map. Instead, the games are broken up into chapters, most of which take place in different locations. This is more like a series of mini-maps characterized by a clearly-defined overarching objective, usually involving the elimination of a particular target. The great thing is it does this without sacrificing the things that often make open-worlds so appealing.

Players still get a decent amount of agency with how they accomplish their objectives, meaning that they are given lots of room to explore each location they visit, even if a lot of that exploration is centered around finding a path towards the main goal. The maps are designed to feel maze-like, featuring lots of options for how they can be navigated, especially when the player character has superpowers. They can battle through hordes of enemies or bypass them entirely. Some maps even include optional side quests or opportunities to interact with other characters. And, of course, they make a point of highlighting big decisions that affect how the story plays out, most notably with deciding on whether to kill a target or find a (usually less obvious) non-lethal solution.

3 Remnant 1 and 2

Who Needs An Open World When There's Procedural Generation?

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Remnant: From the Ashes
Action RPG
Systems
9 /10
7.7 /10
Released
August 20, 2019
ESRB
M for Mature: Blood, Strong Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Gunfire Games
Publisher(s)
Perfect World Entertainment

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

A common aspect of open-world games is that they usually rely on a fixed map. There are exceptions, like No Man's Sky , but usually in order to work, an open-world needs to be carefully designed and planned out. So, naturally, the developers at Gunfire Games decided to try something a bit different in order to give their post-apocalyptic adventure a bit more replayability.

Instead of a solid open-world, with planned quests, encounters, and enemies, both Remnant: From the Ashes and Remnant 2 rely on procedural generation. Put simply, instead of a pre-planned map, the game decides everything while it's running, from the layout to what types of enemies are encountered and in what number. This allows for things to seem random, allowing variety and creating a unique experience for each player, as well as keeping them on their toes since they never know what's around the corner.

2 The Mass Effect Trilogy

Definitive Proof That An RPG Can Work Without An Open-World

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Mass Effect: Legendary Edition
Action
RPG
Systems
9 /10
10
9.7 /10

M for Mature: Blood, Drug Reference, Partial Nudity, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Use of Alcohol, Violence
Developer(s)
BioWare
Publisher(s)
Electronic Arts

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Bioware's iconic sci-fi RPG certainly delivers on the role-playing aspect, but it's not really an open-world in the same way as Skyrim or Fallout . The closest it really gets to being a fully open world is letting Shepard wander around specific areas during quiet moments. Most of the trilogy is structured around being given missions related to the story, sometimes mixed with the occasional side quest. Shepard does get some agency regarding what order to do missions in and can sometimes experience long-term consequences if anything is missed or put off too long, but the missions themselves are pretty linear.

The role-playing aspect is instead found in the details of each mission's story, with Shepard being able to interact with other characters and make decisions that affect how things play out, both in terms of the mission (sometimes determining its success or failure) and future consequences in the overall storyline.

1 The Outer Worlds

A Sci-Fi Romp Across Different Worlds

6 Images
6 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Follow

The Outer Worlds

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Although they had previous success with open-worlds like Fallout: New Vegas , Obsidian decided to try something a bit different with The Outer Worlds . Instead of a full open-world, this one opted for more of an episodic structure, with the plot essentially being broken up into sections that each take place on a different planet in the same Solar System.

While it is technically possible to revisit worlds, and some locations are optional, it's designed to focus on one place at a time. So, there aren't a lot of story missions or quests that require players to jump between planets, for instance. It also means there aren't really options for free space exploration, unlike Outer Wilds , Starfield , or No Man's Sky . However, this has the advantage of making each planet a self-contained and unique experience, allowing for a lot more focus on characters and world-building.

item.title: How To Find Previous Party Member Names In Elden Ring Nightreign?
item.description:
Every expedition in Elden Ring Nightreign is different from the last, no matter how many things you keep the same about your party, characters, and relics. While it's not clear at first, Nightreign keeps a record of all your expeditions, and you can go back to see all sorts of details from any run.

If you end up randomly matchmaking with other players, it can be a roll of the dice for how good your party members are. If you happen to have a great party member but forget to add them after the expedition, you can use your expedition results to go back and find their profile; here's how to do it.

How To Check Expedition History In Elden Ring Nightreign

Expeditions that are completed are logged in the Visual Codex in the Roundtable Hold. When in the Roundtable Hold, head through the door on the left side of the map , on the opposite side of the character change bell. Head into the next room and you'll see the visual codex along the right side of the wall, and interacting with it will bring up the Visual Codex menu.

Even expeditions you leave early will appear in the visual codex.

The very bottom option will be your result history, where you'll see every expedition you've gone on, along with the final results screen showing basic stats from that expedition . Outside the obvious information presented, you can also:

  • Follow the exact path you took during the expedition.
  • See where you got certain rare or legendary loot.
  • See defeated bosses
  • Locations of deaths
  • Locations of revivals

How To Add Old Party Members In Elden Ring Nightreign

In the results screen of any expedition, you'll see the players and characters from your party for that expedition along the right side of the screen. Hover over the player you wish to connect with, and a button prompt will appear in the bottom left corner of the screen letting you view that player's profile .

This brings up that player's system profile, as Elden Ring Nightreign doesn't have a friends list to utilize. You can add that player through whatever social system you choose on your system, then play with them as any other friend. The information from your completed expeditions will always be there, so you can go back and look at the stats of all past party members to decide which ones are the best and worth adding for later runs.

8 Images
8 Images

item.title: 8 Games Where Humanity Is The Bad Guy
item.description:
This list contains spoilers!

Summary

  • Video games let players see humanity as the bad guys in different ways, providing fun and meaningful experiences.
  • Games like Maneater, Terra Nil, and Shadow of the Colossus explore themes of environmental destruction and humanity's darker side.
  • Undertale and Nier: Automata challenge RPG conventions by casting humanity as the villains, offering unique storytelling perspectives.

It doesn't take much of an imaginative leap to conceive of humanity being the bad guys from the perspective of other species, and video games often take this slanted perspective to a new extreme, with entire games being based around humans being the bad guys. Best of all, it's a lot of fun to fight against humanity occasionally.

Sometimes, the player takes the role of a monster that just wants to wreak havoc against the naughty humans, and other times, humans are a sinister force that only becomes clear in the final moments. This list is ranked both by the quality of the game and by how much meaning can be found in humanity being the bad guys.

8 Maneater

Primal Rage

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Maneater
Action RPG
Systems
5 /10
8.0 /10
Released
May 22, 2020
ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Drug Reference, Intense Violence, Mature Humor, Mild Language
Developer(s)
Tripwire Interactive
Publisher(s)
Tripwire Interactive, Deep Silver

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

At the beginning of Maneater , players adopt the perspective of a shark who has experienced a tragedy at the hands of humans. Now, it's time to take revenge, however possible, which mostly involves eating lots of other fish and getting as big as possible to wreak havoc and unlock a litany of awesome abilities.

In the cartoony world of Maneater , the player essentially takes on the role of Jaws, wreaking havoc on humans who are polluting the wildlife and killing innocent animals. It's schlocky but incredible fun with some surprisingly addictive game design thrown in for good measure.

7 Horizon Zero Dawn

Self-Inflicted Apocalypse

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Horizon: Zero Dawn
Action
RPG

Developer(s)
Guerrilla Games
Publisher(s)

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Before Horizon Zero Dawn released, one of the biggest questions going in was what even led to the post-apocalyptic state of the world where the old humanity had disappeared to be replaced by robot dinosaurs and a new tribal society none the wiser about their forebearers.

However, as players discover in the main quest of the game, human beings were pretty awful in their final days, and their own hubris led to their destruction, nearly eradicating the entire planet. Even their creations, such as a rogue AI, linger as a reminder of how far humanity had fallen.

6 The Last Guardian

Trico Trouble

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
The Last Guardian
Action
Adventure
Systems
7 /10
9.5 /10
Released

Developer(s)
JapanStudio, GenDesign
Publisher(s)

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

The Last Guardian was beset by delays and concern ever since its release, and when it finally came out it didn't quite get the critical acclaim that many thought it would. That's a shame, because it's a great game that beautifully follows up the legacy of Shadow of the Colossus by demonstrating how humanity uses violence against what it doesn't understand.

That mostly comes through the experience of Trico, the massive cat/dog/bird/snake creature that guides the protagonist home. Humans hate Trico and react violently to his presence, even if he's just an animal who did nothing wrong. Humanity is seen as irrational, and the tragedy of the game comes from humanity's inability to try and understand Trico and his species, instead of hunting them.

5 Terra Nil

Environmental Disaster

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Terra Nil
Strategy
Tactical
Casual
Systems
Released
March 28, 2023
ESRB
e
Engine
unity

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

Powered by

Climate disaster is a hot-button topic for good reason. There are few crises quite like it, and many people feel powerless to do anything about it. Terra Nil , a novel indie game, came out of nowhere and reinterpreted strategy mechanics to do the opposite of building up humanity's industry, but breaking it down, and helping nature re-take the environment.

Part puzzle game, part strategy, players are tasked with repairing humanity's greed and selfishness by regenerating desolate planets, and, most importantly, cleaning up afterwards as if the player were never there. It's a powerful little game with a great and inspiring message of environmental renewal, as well as being ideal for beginner players.

4 Inside

Industrial Hellscape

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Inside
Puzzle
Platformer
Systems
9 /10
8.4 /10
Released
June 29, 2016
ESRB
M For Mature 17+ due to Blood and Gore, Violence
Developer(s)
Playdead
Publisher(s)
Playdead

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Inside is one of those games that defies description, often better played than described. Yet, its enigmatic nature and complete refusal to explain how the world of humanity had fallen so far make it endlessly compelling to think about, even if the game ends in tragedy.

In the game, players guide a boy through a dystopian state where humans have subjugated themselves and each other to the point where they're almost bestial, conducting inhuman experiments, and hunting outsiders. It's a grim world, but a potent warning of the depths humanity can sink to at its worst.

3 Shadow of the Colossus

Man vs Nature

6 Images
6 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Shadow of the Colossus
Adventure
Action
Puzzle
Systems
8.3 /10
Released
October 18, 2005
ESRB
T For Teen // Blood, Fantasy Violence
Developer(s)
Team Ico
Publisher(s)
Sony Computer Entertainment

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION

Powered by

For a long time in video games, players assumed they were the good guys. After all, they're the ones who are saving the princess, saving the world, and restoring order. While Shadow of the Colossus wasn't the first game to question this assumption, it was the first to question that idea to such an extent that it changed games forever afterwards.

In the game, players are tasked with hunting down massive colossus creatures to save a princess. However, it becomes clear that the incredible colossi are peaceful and never attack first. The player is 100% the bad guy, and other humans are seen as a corrupting force in the realm of nature who trample the dignity of others without a second thought. It's a punchy statement to make, but one that has made the game go down in history as one of the best.

2 Nier: Automata

Humanity Destroys Itself

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
NieR: Automata
Action RPG
Systems
10 /10
9.1 /10
Released
March 7, 2017
ESRB
M for Mature: Blood, Partial Nudity, Strong Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Platinum Games
Publisher(s)
Square Enix

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Nier: Automata is, undoubtedly, one of the very best games ever made. This post-postmodern masterpiece envelops itself in self-reflexive criticism to the point of existential nightmare, with repeated playthroughs adding further knots to the philosophical angst of androids sent to do humans' dirty work of slaughter and mayhem.

Yet, throughout the game, the android characters and the robots they fight start to develop self-awareness of each other, and themselves, as well as questioning how bad the aliens (yep, there are aliens in the game, don't worry about it) really are, too. It's a fantastically knotted story that paints humanity in the worst light possible.

1 Undertale

The Modern Bogeyman

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Undertale
RPG
Systems
10
9.6 /10
Released
September 15, 2015
ESRB
E10+ for Everyone 10+: Fantasy Violence, Mild Blood, Mild Language, Simulated Gambling, Use of Tobacco
Developer(s)
Toby Fox
Publisher(s)
Toby Fox, 8-4

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Though games that try and twist a player's expectations were nothing new in 2015 when Undertale released, it was still remarkable just how revolutionary Undertale was in reconceptualizing the baseline assumptions of RPGs and the role of violence so essential to the genre's functioning.

In the narrative, humans and monsters have become estranged, with monsters being hunted and forced underground. Turns out, the monsters aren't so monstrous after all, and the assumptions of a genocidal humanity is far more dangerous. If the player wants, they can even indulge in a little bit of evil to get a taste.

item.title: What Is Trace Of Night Used For In Elden Ring Nightreign?
item.description:
Elden Ring Nightreign has a key item inventory that players will slowly accumulate a few items in throughout their expeditions as they complete the main story and remembrance quest lines for each character. While the rest of your inventory is lost at the end of an expedition, your key items will stay with you forever.

One of the first key items players will get in Elden Ring Nightreign is the Trace of Night. The uses for this item aren't immediately clear, but it is very important and tied to the main story of the game; here's what it's used for.

***** This article does spoil the name of the final expedition of the game *****

What Is The Trace of Night In Elden Ring Nightreign

Players will get their first Trace of Night upon clearing the first expedition against Gladius. The Trace of Night will be in your key inventory, and the main use for this item is to power it up with additional Traces of Night to eventually unlock the final boss of the game . That being said, the actual mechanics of everything the Trace of Night does happen behind the scenes.

No matter how many Nightlords you beat, you'll only ever have one Trace of Night in your Key items. As you defeat additional Nightlords, it's implied that those Traces of Night merge with the one you have to further power it up, but there is no marker or indication to let you know this is happening. To reach the final boss of the game, you'll need a Trace of Night with four Nightlord charges in it . This means defeating any of the three additional Nightlords that unlock after defeating Gladius, who acts as everyone's first Trace of Night.

After defeating a total of four Nightlords, you'll gain access to the final expedition against the Night Aspect . This expedition will act similarly to all others, but the Nightlord is the final boss of the game, and defeating him will roll credits on the game.

You can complete as many expeditions as you want before facing the final boss, and you can continue doing any expedition after beating the game.

How To Check How Many Nightlords You've Defeated In Elden Ring Nightreign

The Trace of Night will offer no indication of how many Nightlords you've beaten, but you can see how many you've beaten at the expedition menu.

  • Interact with the roundtable to open the expeditions menu.
  • In the, "Targets" tab you'll find every expedition you can complete and the Nightlord for that expedition.

Should there be a black cut through the boss's icon, that means you've defeated it. To unlock the final expedition of the game, you will have to defeat four different Nightlords , as defeating a Nightlord again won't reward you with another Trace of Night.

8 Images
8 Images
